title: The Plural Articles (O -> Oi)
reading_greek:
GROUP 1: NOMINATIVE (Subject)
Singular: Ο δρόμος (The road)
Plural: Οι δρόμοι (The roads)
- Οι δρόμοι είναι μεγάλοι. (The roads are big.)

GROUP 2: ACCUSATIVE (Object)
Singular: Τον δρόμο (The road)
Plural: Τους δρόμους (The roads)
- Βλέπω τους δρόμους. (I see the roads.)

SENTENCE DRILLS:
1. Οι φίλοι είναι εδώ. (The friends are here - Subject)
2. Έχω φίλους. (I have friends - Object / Indefinite)
3. Βλέπω τους φίλους μου. (I see my friends - Object / Definite)
4. Οι άντρες δουλεύουν. (The men are working.)
5. Ακούω τους άντρες. (I hear the men.)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: PLURAL ARTICLES [(See Page 45)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=45)

1. NOMINATIVE: 'O' becomes 'Oi'. 
   - Note: 'Oi' is pronounced exactly like 'H' (ee). 
   - So 'Oi dromoi' sounds like 'Ee dromoi'.

2. ACCUSATIVE: 'Ton' becomes 'Tous'.
   - This is very distinctive. 'Tous' always marks a Masculine Plural Object.

3. FUSION: In the plural nominative, Masculine 'Oi' looks identical to Feminine 'Oi'. 
   - Masculine: Oi dromoi.
   - Feminine: Oi ores.
audio_script:
The Article is King, even in Plural. 

For Masculine nouns:
- The Subject (Nominative) 'O' changes to 'Oi'. 
- The Object (Accusative) 'Ton' changes to 'Tous'.

So: 'O filos' (The friend) -> 'Oi filoi' (The friends). 
'Ton filo' (The friend, object) -> 'Tous filous'. 

Pay attention to 'Tous'. It is a very strong, masculine sound. If you hear 'Tous', you know it's a Masculine Plural Object. 
'Vlepo tous filous' (I see the friends).

quiz_questions.explanation: You must know the gender from the singular.
